cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office, London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.Le reaesu de eables telegraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie constitue le moyen de communication le plus direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amerique du Nord et du Sud, l'Afrique orientale, meridionale et occidentale, les Indes, l''Austraile, la Nouvelle-Zelande, la Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les telerammee doivent porter l'indication Via Eastern.Voir le tempe moyen de transmission le plus recent jusque Londres au bulletin journalier publie dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Bureau priscipal a Londres.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Continual calm weather prevailed throughout yesterday, followed at midnight by a flat calm, with a calm sea, the weather being slightly hasy. A little dew fell throughout the night. Barometer steady.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1904.

div.head: STREET NOMENCLATURE.
div.p: Some months ago the Post Office Administration notified the public that in future correspondents should, in addressing their letters, never fail to give the name of the street and the number of the house where the addressee resided. The penalty for failing to comply with this regulation was delay in the delivery of the letters imperfectly addressed. It was pointed out in our columns at the time that many streets in Cairo were utterly unbaptizes, while more often than not the Public Works Administration appeared to regard the affixing of numbers to houses as one of the superfluities of civilization. After the Post Office Administration had issued the notice in question, some attempts were made by the Public Works Department to name a few streets in Cario, but it appears that the efforts have been relaxed for there are many streets in the Capital which are innocent of any designation whatsoever. We may instance three or four streets running off the Kasr-el-Ainy-road, on the left as one goes towards the hospital from Kasr-el-Nil Bridge. These streets are nameless, and therefore the regulation of the Post office cannot be complied with. It has been maliciously rumoured that the reason why so many streets are unnamed is because of the jealousy among officials, who cannot come to any agreement among themselves and to which of them shall be immortalized by christening the streets with their own names. This is ridiculous, for the modesty of our official classes is proverbial. But we fail to see any reason why the names of prominent Anglo-Egyptians should not figure on the street as well as those of native notables, such as Idris Bey Ragheb, whose name adorns a street near El Daher, and also in other cases. At Alexandria we have streets named after Goussio, Adib, Antonisdis, Gordon, Mariette, and numerous other local notabilties. Surely there are plenty of officials belonging to the Public Works Department or the Ministries of Justice and the Interior whose names would be useful for these streets ! Such names as Garstin, Dunlop, or McIlwraith might fittingly be adapted to street nomenclature. As the roads we have mentioned are in the neighbourhood of the new schools by the Kasr-el-Ainy-road it would be appropriate to use some of the names of the high officials in the Ministry of Public Instruction, such as that of Dr. Dunlop, Yacoub Pasha Artin, etc. The opportunities thus afforded for immortalizing many names whose owners are closely connected with the development of modern Egypt would be unllimited, as new streets are springing up daily. Another plan, in case of disagreement, would be to put the matter up to an auction, as there must be many who would be only too eager to see their names inscribed on the walls of Cairo for all time. The sum realised should be of great utility in swelling the revenues of the Tanzim Department, which pleads poverty as an excuse for neglecting its duties towards the public.
Five submarines arrived at Yokohama to-day. The bombardment by the naval guns ignited the buildings near the Arsenal at Port Arthur. They were burning all yesterday. (Reuter.)
The buildings situated near the Arsenal at Port Arthur have been set on fire by the Japanese naval guns. Five submarines have arrived at Yokohama (Havas.)

div.head: JAPAN BUYING WELSH COAL.
div.p: Japan is again buying Welsh steam coal. Several Cardiff firms are making offers. One purchase of 10,000 tons has been recorded (Reuter.)

div.head: CREW OF THE "RAZTORPAY."
div.p: The crew of the Ratztorpay will be conveyed to Shanghai by the Chinese cruiser Haiyung with the consent of the Japanese and Russian Governments. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN INTERRESTS.
THREATENED BY GREAT BRITAIN.
div.p: The Rus urges Russia to defend her interests in the Near and Middle East with greater vigour than ever, otherwise south-eastern Persia and the Gulf will soon be British possessions. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE NORTH SEA OUTRAGE.
MEMORIAL TO VICTIMS.
div.p: A memorial by public subscription will be erected here for the victims of the Baltic Fleet. (Reuter.)

div.head: CHINA AND THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
div.p: China has consented to be represented at the Hague Conference. (Reuter.)

div.head:
RUSSIAN REFORM.
THE ZEMSTVOS MEETING.
div.p: The meeting of the zemstvos closed yesterday evening. Though held privately, it attracted the greatest attention. The discussions, which were unrestricted, covered a wide field. The greatest unanimity in favour of reform was manifested. The delegates will present a programine to the Minister of the Interior, and it is repeated that the same will be received by the Tsar. (Reuter.)

div.head:
A TURKISH EXPEDITION.
TURKEY BUYING CAMELS.
div.p: Turkey is purchasing a large number of camels at Basra: it is believed they are for an expedition into the Nejd country against the chief Ibn Saied. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive is expected to return to Cairo on Friday evening or Saturday morning.

div.head: A MAD DOG
div.p: bit a native girl of 6 years, yesterday, near the Alexandria Custonm-house. She has been sent to Cairo for treatment at the Anti-Rabic Institute.

div.head: NEW ROADS.-
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works proposes to make new roads at Zeitoun and Matarieh. Proprietors of land in these places will, it is hoped, facilitate matters by coming to the assistance of the Ministry.

div.head: TELEPHONE Co. OF EGYPT.-
div.p: Application has been made to the London Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day in and to grant a quotation to: Telephone Company of Egypt, <pound symbol>60,000 4 ½ per cent. Debenture Stock.

div.head: SUDAN EXPLORATION.-
div.p: An application has been made to the London Stock Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day in Sudan Exploration, further issue of 15,000 shares of 10s, each fully paid, Nos.40,008 to 55,007.

div.head: RAILWAY ACCIDENT.-
div.p: A train on the Ramleh Electric Railway ran over and severly injured a native yesterday near Chatby station. The driver of the car has been arrested. The injured man is lying in the Government Hospital, where no hope is entertained of his recovery,

div.head: CHURCH OF SCOTLAND WOMAN'S GUILD.-
div.p: A sale of work in connection with the St. Andrew's branch of the guild will be held in the boys upper school, Missala quarter, on Friday, 16th December. After defraying the expenses of material, etc., the proceeds will go towards the purchase of a piano for the Seamen's Home.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.-
div.p: On the 21st inst. 8 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 7 were British and 1 Dutch. The transit and passenget dues for the day amounted to 237,626.86 frs. The total transit an passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 256 vessels amounted to 6,848,766.41 francs.

div.head: M. SIEVAIN,
div.p: the celebrated French actor, is paying a return visit to Alexandria to-morrow. In the afternoon he will deliver a lecture at the Khedivial Hotel on "L' Art de Dire" and in the evening, by special request, will appear at the Zizinia Theatre in Moreas's Iphigenie, in which he scored a huge succes at a performance given recently in the Stadium at Athens

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: It is said that H.H. the Khedive will confer the rank of Mirmiran (pasha) on Mohamed Bey Surur, of the Wakfs Administration, in the coming year.
Lord Cromer paid a visit last Monday to the Survey Department at Gizeh.
The Persian Consul at Alexandria left for Cairo yesterday.
Seandar Pasha Fehmy left yesterday for Cairo by the noon train.
Captain Hall, R.E., goods manager of the State Railways, is, we are sorry to hear, suffering from an attack of diphtheria, and is an inmate of the Deaconsesses' Hospital, Cairo.
Mr. H.A. Gwyne, the new editor of the Standard, is well known in Egypt and the Sudan, as he was a special correspondent up the Nile during a number of campaigns.

Mr. C.A. Osborne, of Suakin, who went to Europe last month to consult Professor Pagenstecker, the world-renowned oculist of Wiesbanden, received such benefit from his treatment that he has now left Germany for London and hopes to be able to sail on his return to Suakin about the 20th December.

div.head:
ARRIVAL AT PORT SAID.
NEARLY A COLLISION.
SHIPPING STOPPED.
PRESENCE OF JAPS,
div.p: Reuter's correspondent at Canea confirms the report of the disgraceful conduct of some of the men belonging to the Baltic Fleet. Constant scenes of drunkenness took place in which several officers participated. One Russian was killed by his comrades, whilst others were severly wounded. The officers were disregarded, and there was no discipline. Many of the seamen were left behind, being either lost or having deserted. (Reuter.)
The Fleet will be off the port at 5 a.m. tomorrow, 24th inst. The Canal Company have allotted berths to them as follows:-
Opposite Rive Asie Island in order running North to South:-
No. 1. Jupiter.
2. Kitai.
3. Setlina.
4. Anathe.
Nos. 5 to 10 Torpedo Destroyers.
No. 11. Lissoi Veliky,
12. Navarin.
13. Almaz.
14. Varoney.
15. Veadimia.
They will be allowed to take fresh water and provisions on board, but no coal.
I have it on good authority that a portion of the Mediterranean Squadron will be within call of the guard-ship here, but cannot say if the Fleet will be followed through the Canal.
The Russian Consul-General and the head officials of the Suez Canal Company have arrived here to-noght. They will meet the Baltic Fleet to-morrow.
The Greek Squadron left a 3 p.m. to-day- It will probably pass the Russians during the night.
The Canal will be cleared of all traffic during the passage of the fleet.
Agents of the Japanese Government are here watching events. Rumors of the presence of Japanese warships off Aden are to hand.

The Russian Squadron, coming from Suda Bay, is in sight. The ships are entering one after the other. It is believed they will remain a few hours in the port. Every precaution has be taken for their passage through the Canal. The Greek Squadron left yesterday for Syra.
At 2 o'clock this morning the Russian Consul-Gerneral, M. Maximoff, and some pilots left the port to meet the fleet on its way here.
At 4 o'clock four of the Russian destroyers arrived and anchored in the outer harbour. Four warships and eight store ships arrived later. The store ships anchored while the warships kept on the move.
At daylight the rest of the flet entered the harbour, and there was nearly a collision.
The ships in the harbour were not allowed to leave while the fleet was entering.
The colliers carry Cardiff coal loaded in Sebastopol. There are naval crews on all the store ships. The officers are reported to be smart, while the crews are very inefficient.

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGPYTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Sir,-Referring to the Port Said Notes in your issue of yesterday's date, might I suggest that as a measure of precaution the authorities be requested to suspend the firing of the Ramadam gun at Port Said, Ismalia and Suez during the passage of the Baltic Fleet through the Suez Canal. In their present chronic state of nervousness, there is no knowing what the famous Fleet may be capable of doing, if they are startled by the firing of the gun.
I am, etc.,

div.head: Says the Pall Mall Gazette:-
div.p: The Suez Canal is to be padded with cotton wool for the passage of the "Second Pacific Squadron." That is to say, not only will there be special protection of the banks and a suspension of all northward traffic to give the warships an uninterrupted passage, but the captains of all ships are to receive strict orders to refrain from throwing anything into the Canal until the ships are through, and to prevent any kind of demonstration. These precautions are most commendable. The nerves of the North Sea heroes must be thought of. It is terrible to thimk of what might happen if any British mercantile seamen were thoughtless enough to tap out his pipe overboard within sight of a fleet that might misinterpret his action, to say nothing of throwing over ashes or banana-skins. The rule against demonstrations is likewise to the good. A misconcieved wink or simle, seen through a Russian telescope, might produce the direst complications. We have to remember that when such a fleet as this becomes neurotic it is others who suffer.

div.head:
SUDDEN DEATH ON BOURSE.
SENSATION IN CITY.
div.p: Mr. Augustine Salvago, a broker belonging to the firm of Cumbo, Maximoff & Co., on the Alexandria Bourse, died under tragic circumstances this morning. At about half-past ten o'clock, he was sitting in the cafe of the Bourse taking a cup of coffee, when he was siezed with a heart failure and died on the spot.

A few minutes before he had received a telegram concerning his business and sat down awaiting a confirmatory wire. While seated he was joined by a friend, who addressed him with a salutation several times but received no reply, as Mr. Salvago had already lost the power of articulation. Seeing that Mr. Salvago was seriously ill, he called for a waiter, who fetched Dr. Lian, the latter happening to be on the Bourse. Dr. Lian was afterwards joined by another medical man, and both did everything called for by the circumstances, but unavailingly. Mr. Salvago was removed to a bench in the Bourse, where he died a few minutes afterwards, without having again spoken. His body was subsequently removed to his residence.
Deceased, who was about 50 years of age, leaves a widow and three children, two of whom are girls.
The occurrence caused a great sensation in the city, and crowds gathered in the immediate neigbourhood of the Bourse. Business was suspended for fifteen minutes as a sign of respect.

After Mr. Salvago had breathed his last a disgraceful scence occurred in the cafe, where the corpse lay. Crowds of eager sightseers jostled one another in their desire to view the body. The coffee tables and chairs were used as points of vantage, and the crowding was terrible. No serious attempt was made to deal with the crowd.

div.head: DEATH OF BEWLEY BEY.
div.p: The death of Bewley Bey in England yesterday, announced in a private telegram received by us this morning, has been expected for some time as he was in failing health for many months and was suffering from an incurable malady, viz., spinal paralysis. Lately he had completely lost his reason, which necessitated his being put under restraint and confined in a private home.

Bewley Bey, who was related to the late Captain Beyts of Suez, came out originally to Europe about 30 years ago and was employed for a short time in the firm of Beytz & Co. of that town. He subsequently joined the ill-fated expedition that was sent to Suakin shortly after under Baker Pasha, and on the almost completeannihilation of that force that followed, he was appointed to the police service. He was afterwards named director of the Public Security Department at the Ministry of the Interior, succeeding Colonel Kelly Bey, on the latter's retirement about three years ago, to the important post of director of the Police Stores Department at Boulac on a salary of L.E. 900 per annum.
Bewley Bey, who left Cairo last summer on sick leave, leaves a widow and several children, for whom the deepest sympathy is felt by the whole British community of the Capital.
Deceased was in posession of the Egyptian Medal and Bronze Star, as well as the 4th Class Medijidieh and 4th Class Osmanieh.

div.head: CANAL NAVIGATION.
div.p: All the canals in Menoufieh and Gharbieh provinces will be lowered or closed for works in connection with the annual clearances on December 20, and navigation will be difficult, if not impossible, from that date until the 20th of January.
The lock at Santa will be completely closed to navigation and the Bagouria Canal will be quite impassable; therefore, through navigation from Alexandria to Cairo will only be possible by the river.

In consequence of winter clearances the canals in 1st Circle of Irrigation will be closed from December 20 for about 30 days with the exception of the Ismalia Canal, which will be open for the navigation of small boats only.
Navigation in Gharbieh province will be stopped in all canals from 15th December, for about 30 days.
Navigation in Dakalieh province will be stopped in all canals from 10th December, for about 30 days.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY.
div.p: The committee of the Khedivial Agricultural Society has approved the scheme for the extension of the work of this society which has been under consideration for some time past.
The general meeting of the society, which will be held shortly, will discuss the decisions arrived at by the committee and decide on the measures to be taken.
The Government is doing everything to further the work of the society, and in future, we understand, a few officials of the Government will have a seat on the committee.

div.head: ALAHAMBRA THEATRE.
div.p: Last night, on the occasion of the final appearance of the tenor G. Apostolu, Rigoletto was given. The theatre vas crowded, and the artistes were frantically applauded. Foremost amongst them we may mention Mme Aida Gonzaga, who, in the role of Gilda, displayed the full force of her talent as a singer and comedienne. The barytone Arrighetti was perfect in the two first acts, but appeared tired towards the end. The tenor Apostolu was splendid from beginning to end. He had to repeat "Donna e mobile" in the 4th act. The orchestra played admirable throughout the piece.

div.head:
THE BAHR-EL-GHAZAL.
FEAR OF INVASION.
div.p: The Matin of Paris publishes an extraordinary piece of news from Brussels. This is to the effect that the Congo State is actively engaged in putting the Lado enclave of the Bahr-et-Ghazal into a state of defence capable of resisting an invasion by England, which it is declared there is serious reason to fear. The port of Lado, which is being armed with 9-inch guns, is intended to control the river, and there is a land force of 6,000 native troops inured to the deadly climate, which, it is believed, would be fatal to Sudanese. A war levy would raise the number to 18,000 men.

div.head:
THE SWAMI RAMA.
VISIT TO CAIRO.
div.p: The Swami Rama, who has been recently staying with Mr. and Mrs. Plunkett at the "De Rouge," Cairo, has left for Benares. The Swami, who is a M.A. of the University of Lahore, has been giving a series of lectures at the principal universities in the U.S. of America on theosophy and kindred subjects. During his stay in the Capital he has addressed meetings of the Hindus resident in Cairo and has succeeded in persuading them to form a society which is to devote itself to the settlement of disputes between Hindus resident in the city. He had also urged the Hindus to abstain from all quarrels with their Moslem neighbours. The Swami recently dined with the Grand Mufti, who received him with great respect and kindness.

To prevent any misconceptions, we may say that this teacher is absolutely faithful to the rules of his order, which forbid him to accept money for the teaching of philosophy. Those who have met him speak highly of his self-denial and zeal.

div.head: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE. IMPORTANT REFORM.
div.p: The Judicial Adviser is to be sincerely congratulated on having organised a remarkable reform in the English personnel of the Ministry of Justice. Mr. McIlwraith has discovered that it is necessary for the English judges and other English officials of the Ministry of Justice to have some acquaintance with Arabic, for there are some English judges on the Bench of the Native Courts who have made no attempt to acquaint themselves even with the spoken Arabic of Egypt. Considering the number of years that some of these judges have been appointed, their slacknes in this respect is a public scandal, and it has been a matter for surprise that the Judicial Adviser should have allowed this state of things to continue for so long. Yesterday, however, the Journal Official published an arrete of the Ministry of Justice on the subject, which begins with a charming naivite:--

"Vu la necessite pour certains magistrats et fonctionnaires etraugers dependant du Ministere de la Justice de connaitre la langue arabe et vu l'opportunite de mettre en rapport l'examen a subir avec la nature du travail qu'ils auront a effectuer,"

The arrete goes on to describe the subjects required for two examinations which are to be instituted. It is very noticeable that there is no trace in the arrete of the examination being obligatory, so that the favoured proteges, who are so indifferent to their professional dutues as to refuse to make themselves acquainted with Arabic, will still, we presume, be allowed to occupy their seats on the Bench, and will never bother themselves about their examination.

div.head: QUARANTINE.
div.p: A telegram from Rome sttes that by a maritime sanitary ordinance, dated the 22nd inst., the preceding ordinance against Alexandria has been abrogated.
Another telegram from Constantinople states that the medical inspection imposed on arrivals from Damietta has been done away with.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: 13 deaths from cattle plague were repoted in Egyptduring the last week, and 62 inoculations were performed.
No new localities were reported infected during the week.

div.head: YACHTING.
div.p: The steam yacht Argonaut arrived at Port Said early yesterday morning from Haifa and landed 84 tourists who proceeded to Cairo.
The English steam yacht Emerald, owned by Sir Christopher Furness, M.P., arrived at Port Said from Alexandria on Tuesday evening at dusk, and remains.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Niger, which left Alexandria on the 18th inst., arrived at Marseilles at 6 a.m. yesterday.

The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal, having had to wait at Beyrout for the mails, did not leave that port till last night, and is therefore not due here till Friday evening or Saturday morning. The hour of her departure for Marseilles will be announced in due course.
The S.S. Asiatic Prince, from the Tyne and London, left Malta on Wednesday and is due here on Sunday next, with passengers and general cargo.
The S.S. Scottish Prince, from Antwerp, left London on Tuesday last, with passengers and general cargo, for Malta and Alexandria.

div.head:
NUNGOVICH HOTELS CO.
CAUSE OF THE TROUBLE.
div.p: We have received the following account of the causes which lead to the resignation of four of the members of the board of directors of the Nungovich Hotels Company from an extremely well-informed source.

It appears that early last summer the board of directors decided to begin the building of the new Savoy Restauraunt against the opinion expressed by Nungovich Bey that a start was not advisable before April, 1905. This decision was made towards the end of May, but nothing, as a mteer of fact, was done till the middle of June, when Nungovich Bey wrote begging Mr. J. Cattaui not to commence before September, wishing to be present himself to superintend this very delicate work, at which an accident might easily occur during the necessary alterations, moving of walls, etc.

Mr. Cattaui not only took no notice of Nungovich Bey's expression of opinion but, on the contrary, gave orders that the work should begin at once. After these orders had been given both Mr. Cattaui and the architect left for Europe. Mr. Nungovich, in the meantime, had sent a telegram to him protesting against what he described as an unjustifiable decision, and stating that Mr. Cattaui must consider himself responsible for any loss or damage that might ensue.

At the last meeting of the board of directors, Sir Elwin Palmer called upon Nungovich Bey to withdraw the statements contained in the telegram but met with a steady refusal. In consequence thereof Mr J. Cattaui resigned his directorship, followed by Sir Elwin Palmer, Sir John Rogers, and Rustovich Bey, George Nungovich Bey, and Dr. Page-May now represent the board of directors.

div.head: DEPARTURE OF GREEK FLEET.
div.p: Port Said, Wednesday.--The Greek Fleet left Port Said this afternoon for Syra with a "send-off" which equalled the reception in enthusiasm. The programme arranged by the committee was carried out in every particular. The Commodore and 3 staff officers dined with Mr. Coroni on Monday evening, and invitations were issued for a small dance after the dinner. A Te Deum service, celebrated by the Patriarch Photius, yesterday morning, was attended by all the officers and 150 sailors. In the evening a grand banquet was given at the Continental Hotel, at which the Patriarch was present. The decorations in the national colours were most elaborate, and call for special notice. The dinner was followed by a performance of "Voscopoula" at the Theatre Eldorado, the night's festivities ending with a supper and dance.

div.head: KING'S MEDITERRANEAN CRUISE.
div.p: According to the Daily Mail, the King will take a yachting cruise up the Mediterranean shortly after Lord Charles Beresford hoists his flag in these waters. Calls will be made both at Gibraltar and Malta.

div.head: TRADE OF SUEZ.
div.p: In a report on the trade of Suez H. M's Pro-Consul there makes the following remarks:--

"The general trade at the port of Suez for the year 1903 shows and increase of L.E. 210,916 as compared with the year 1902. This increase is chiefly due to the revival of the export trade: which is attributed mainly to the abolition of the quarantine restrictions imposed against arrivals from Egypt at Jeddah and other Red Sea ports during the year, and to the revival of trade generally with Eastern ports."

The imports of indigo increased in quantity but decreased value, the Madras indigo valued at 4s. 1d. per kilo being now more largely imported than that from Bengal at 6s. 7d. per kilo. This cheaper natural quality is brought into the country to compete with the artificial product, of which increasing quantities are sent over form Germany.

Cotton yarn from India was in 1903 nearly double what it was in 1902; the total import being over 201,000 kilos, valued at L.E. 10,415; which compensates for the decline in the supply from Great Britian, as we have already mentioned in our allusions to the report of the Consul General of Alexandria.

The export of Egyptian cane sugar has increased by L.E. 140,000 during the year; 23,000 tons having been exported in 1908, as against 4,000 tons in 1900. The export of gum shows a decrease of L.E. 14,000, and ivory of L.E. 8,000 on the previous year.

Out of a total import of L.E. 739,000, the British possessions in the Far East supply L.E. 456,000, and the Turkish Dominions L.E. 126,000; China with L.E. 63,001, and Persia with L.E. 199,000, Turkey L.E. 83,000, and Great Britain L.E. 71,000.

div.head:
BANKING IN EGYPT.
"BANCO DI ROMA" AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: A correspondent in Egypt of Itale, the French daily newspaper published at Rome, sends the following information re the establishment of a branch of the Banco di Roma at Alexandria to that journal:--

Nal n'ignore ce pert d'Alexandrie sur le quais duquel ruissellent constaninent des produits de toute sorte et nul n'ignore le Caire, cette capitale qui devient de plus en plus une station hivernale vers laquelle affluent chaque hiver des milliers de touristes de tous paye. La vieille Egypte tend a se rapprocher de la vielle Europe et semble en fiare partie. Depuis Pantiquite la plus reculee la vallee dn Nil fut oujours hospitaliere aux estrangers et les hebreux eux-memes, apres leur fameuse captivite regrettaient les orgnons d'Egypte.

Depuis, Mhement-Aly, le fondateur de la dynastie actuelle, et tous les souverains qui lui ont sucede, n'ontcesse d'attirer l'entranger, medecins, ingenieurs, commercants, et les conventions commerciales ont ouvert les marchee egyptiens aux produite francais, italiens, anglais, allemands, etc. De plus le regime des tributaux de la reforme, etabli d'apres le code Napoleon, offrant les memes suretes que celui de n'importe quel pays civilise, avec cette difference toutefois, que le taux des placements varie de 6 a 9 pour cent,--ce qui fair que les capitaux etrangers affluent de toutes parts,--les diverses nations se sont empressees de fonder des banques ou des succursales qui toutes sont prosperes et florissantes.

Il n'y avait que I'Itale dont la colonie est pourtant l'une des plus annciennee et importantes tant au point de vue commerciale qui seule jusqu'a ce jour n'avat un etablissement national. Il y avait la une lacune a combler. Or, la Banque de Rome eut la premiere l'honner de songer a cembler cette lacune. Et comme M. Ernest Pacelli, president du Banco di Roma, est un homme actify et, quoique entrerenant, n'agit jamais a la legere, il quitta ses occupations nombreuses a Rome et entrainant deux ses collegues, M.M.Tittoni et Benucci, se rendit en Egypte pour y etudier la question sur place. Sa capacite, le don des affaires, dirons-nous aussi, lui permirent immediatement de sasir tout l'avantage tant commercial que politique que l'Italie peurrait tirer de l'etablissement d'une maison de banque italienne en Egypte.

Actuellemeut le premier grand pas est fait et grace a la consideration dont jouit M. Pacelli, grace a la confiance enorme qui le suit, l'effort tente a reussi, et bientot l'Italie aura aussi une banque italienne, la Banque de Rome.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: Events in the political world, which always have so much bearing on matters financial, have not advanced quite so quickly as our last might have led your readers to expect. Frequent meetings, however, of the leading Diplomatic Representatives are still taking place, and there are hopes that shortly these may bear fruit on the lines indicated. The Afghan scare has been given a great deal too much prominence by the Press here; the Bears have not been slow to take advantage of this, as also the statement that there is a hitch in the final adjustment of the Dogger Bank trouble. I am assured there is no cause for further anxiety as to the latter, and as to the former, in diplomatic circles, it is not believed to have any foundation in fact. In spite of the setback which has taken place in almost every market during the present week, mainly from the above causes, Egyptians still remain not merely firm, but buoyant. Salt and Soda shares continue to meet with strong support from interested quarters, and the price has touched 1-15/16. A few shares came in at this level, and brought the price back to 36/6, but as a market they are still strong enough to warrant a further rise on the shortage of shares, though on their merits the price would appear high. National Banks have been well bought to-day and the price has advanced to 24 buyers, whilst Agriculturals are firm at 11. Delta Lands are steady at 2 ½, and might easily to better, as the supply of shares is small.

In general markets, the long 19-day account has had its usual effect, and there was a decided check early this week, especially in Kaffirs and Americans, in both of which there is now a pretty large professional Bull position open. The undertone, however, remains good, and the end of the month should show better prices and firmer markets again all round, in the absence of any political complications, of which there is less fear now than there has been for some time past.

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALE
div.p: La Bibliotheque

Il est question en ce moment d'ajouter une aile de batiment a la Bibliotheque Municipale d'Alexandrie, afin de suppleer a l'insuffisance de la salle actuelle. Avant de proceder a ce travail, il serait opportun, eroyons-nous, d'etudier avec soin la question de l'emplacement. Le role d'une bibliotheque publique etant d'instruire et de moraliser les foules, un pareil etablissment doit necessairement etre situe en un point central, a la portee de tout le monde. Or, la situation du Palais Municipal est un peu excentrique; le public se rassemble de preference dans les environs de la Place Mohamed Ali et c'est done l'emplacement tout indique pour une bibliotheque.
Nous esperons que la Commission Municipale, avant de faire les frais d'agrandissement proposes, etudiers soigneusement cette question.

L'Egypte, peut-on dire, a ete le berceau des biblioteques, comme e le a ete le berceau des sciences. La plus ancienne que l'on connaisse fut fondee par Osymandiss a Thebes. On lissait sur la porte cest mots significatifs: Pharmacie de l'ame. C'est, en effet, le role du livre de guerir l'ame de la plaie de l'ignorance. La Ville d'Alexandrie eut bientot sa bibliotheque et c'est la plus celebre de l'antiquite dont l'histoire ait garde le souvenir. Elle fut fondee par Ptolemee Soter yers 290 avant J.-C.-.Elle contenait, au moment de sa distruction par Amrou en 640, environ 700,000 volumes.

Si nous avons rappele en quelques mots le passe glorieux de l'Egypte et surtout d'A;exandrie dans l'histore des sciences, c'est pour encourager la Municipalite a profiter des cironstances actuelles exceptionnellement favorables pour jeter les bases d'une vraie bibliotheque nationale. Elle dispose de vastes etendues de terrain. Porquoi n'en reserverait-elle pas une partie pour l'emplacement d'une bibliotheque,pres des Postes par exemple? L'exccution d'un projet aussi utile lui ferait pardonner bien des fautes et attacherait a son nom un souvenir inoubliable.

La bibliotheque actuelle, bien qu'elle soit publique, est peu frequentee. Elle est presque inconnue a la majorite des habitants. Pour la mettre a la portee de la masse, il faudrait la transporter au centre de la ville et la laisser ouverte au moins jusq'a minuit. Les personnes qui ont un emploi, une occupation qui les retient a l'atelier ou au comptoir pendant la journee, ceux et celles qui ont le plus besoin d'instruction, les ouvriers et les ouvrieres particuliere-mont, ne peuvent pas frequenter les bibliotheques dans la journee. Il n'y a guere que les oisifs, les hommes de lettres et les savants de profession, qui puissant consulter les tresors renfermes dans nos bibliotheques dans de teiles conditions. Encore le nobre d'heures consacrees aux etudes aux recherches dans la journee est-il beaucoup trop restreint. Il importe evid mment de remedier a ces inconvenients, en rendant la bibliotheque accessible daus la soiree, dut-on doubler le nombre des conservateurs et des employes. Combien de gens vont respirer l'atmosphere malsaine des estaminets et des theatres qui iraient developper leur intelligence et augmentor leura connaissances, si les bibliotheques etaient ouvertes le soir! Et nous ne parlons pas des villes et villages de l'interieur ou la situation est vraiment deplorable sous ce rapport.

Nous recevons a l'appui de notre these plusieurs lettres d'Alexandrins qui se plaignent du peu de service que rend a la ville la bibliotheque municipale. L'eloignement, l'hoiraire, le choix des livres, tout contrible a ecarter le lecteur. L'employe qui sort de son burau a 6 heures arriverait juste a temps pour voir fermer les portes. O'est bien pis pour l'ouvrier qui sort encore plus tard de son chantier. Le choix des livres est egalement defectueux. Dans un pays essentiellement agricole comme l'Egypte, la part faite aux ouvrages traitant d'agriculture est trop resorient, presque nulle.
Aussi quelques rares desoeuvres, seuls, viennent-ils de temps a autre trainer leurs savates dans la salle de la bibliotheque.

Esperons que la Commission mettra bientot un terme a toutes ous plaintes en affectant a la bibliotheque municipale un emplacement convenable, en en modifiant l'horaire et en en comblant les lacunes par trop regrettables.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demi)
Les actions de Suez ont attient hier soir le prix de 4,563 francs et la tendance est toujours pour la hausse.

LaComission Internationale des travaux du Canal, dans sa derniere séance, a decide de creer un port de commerce a Port-Said, qui desservirait toute la moitie orientale de l'Egypte. On said que la moitie occidentale est desservie par Alexandrie La Commission a egalement decide de porter partout la profondeur du canal a dix metres. Ce sont ces recentes decisions qui viennent de doner un nouvel essort aux actions de Suez.
Ici le marche est plutot calme et les transactions peu nombreuses. Cependant les Cotton Mills continuent a hausser et atteignent maintenant 10 shellings 3 pence acheteurs.

La hausse subite des Cotton Mills est due a la rumeur d'une fusion avec l'Anglo Egyptian Spinning and Weaving Company. Jusqu'ici la nouvelle n'est pas confirmee; o'est pourquoi les acheteurs restent indecis.
Ce matin les Lots Turcs qui etaient restes longtemps stationnaires ont donne lieu a une forte demande. Les cours sont montes de 126 a 128 acheteurs. Beaucoup d'echanges ont eu lieu a ces prix.
Les Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte ont flexhi de 210 a 204 acheteurs.

Les recettes des Markets accusent cette semaine une diminution de pres de moitre sur les recettes de la semaine correspondante de 1903; elles sont de 469 L.E. contre 9/1 L.E. l'annee se troube donc jusqu'ici inferieur d'un tiers a celui de 1903; le cours faiblit a 26/9 vendeurs.
Par suite du dementi donne a la demission de M. George Nungovich, la valeur a repris a 9 1/8 vendeurs. Nous donnons des details a ce suject dans notre partie anglaise.
Une hausse remarquable c'est celle des Eaux d'Alexandrie a 17 ¾, et des Eaux du Caire a 1140 acheteurs.

Par ailleurs le marche est lourd avec tendance a la baisse: la Banque Nationale flechit a 24 acheteurs, la Crown Brewery a 224, la Salt and Soda a 89, l'Anglo-American Nile a 5 ¼, la Delta Light a 15 1/16, les Privilegiees Tramways a 146 et les Dividendes a 885.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT.
Liverpool November 17.
Egyptian Cotton has been in moderate demand this week, the selection here is poor, and spinners only buy for their immediate requirements. Good and Fine Brown, and Fine Upper are 1/8 dearer.
In Futures an active business has been done at advancing prices, caused by the animated state of the Alexandria Market.
The following are the closing quotations:--

American Futures. The market this week has experienced moderate fluctuations, a gradual hardening up of 10 points, which in turn have been lost, leaving to-day's closing values practically unchanged from those of last Thursday. The position remains featureless, large Crop movements, although perhaps not quite so large as expected, and a continuous large demand fairly balance one another, whilst as regards prices they seem just to reflect the uncertainty of the average opinion. 5 ¼ d. to 5 1/2d. with a Crop of about 11 ½ millions can neither be looked upon as an unreasonably low price nor is it an unreasonably high price when the requirements of the world, after four seasons of short supplies, are taken into consideration. Any material variation up or down in values will therefore apparently be due to Crop news falling below 11 ½ millions or to estimates of a larger yield.

div.head: THE IDEAL HUSBAND.
div.p: English authors have ceased to write books on how to choose a husband, finding perhaps that the wilful maiden of to-day has very deaf ears. In Italy, however, woman is still to some extent under the yoke, and is no doubt giving to Signor Mantegazza's book the thoughtful consideration it deserves. At the same time the writer is certainly a little difficult to please. It must be depressing for any fair reader, intent on matrimony, to come at the very outset on this list of husbands who ought to be avoided :-
BAD HUSBANDS.
TYRANTS. MISERS.
MILKSOPS. PROFLIGATES.
OTHELLOS. FOOLS.
GRUMBLERS. Do-NOTHINGS (IDLERS).

Who of us all can lay his hand on his heart and say his withers are unwrung ? How many Benedicks can avoid Censures 1 and 2 by being not too assertive, but just assertive enough? And what, after all, are the justifiable limitations of marital grumbling in, relation, say, to (a) cold mutton, (b) dress bills, (c) mother-in- laws' visits? Here is food for much argument ; and it is easier for Signor Mantegazza to say that a husband should be neither too stubborn nor too weak than for his anxious reader to find that paragon of a man.

The lady is not, however, left without help in her quest. Signor Mantegazza's test for the miser is to "watch him particularly when he pronounces the words 'million' or 'million- aire.'' If he "swells with pride," even if he "raises the pitch of his voice," give him his conge : he is no meet husband. The wise virgin is. also recommended to avoid young gentlemen who use the first personal pronoun overmuch-here you see the Tyrant-and also such as kiss the maid-servant (Fault No. 6). "Fools" may dissemble their vacuity during courtship by getting up their information ; wherefore the prudent damsel will read Stuart Mill and Herbert Spencer, and be in a position to detect stolen syllogisms. In other matters also the English habit is to be studied, for (under the heading of the eighth Deadly Sin) we learn that. "In many countries of Europe and America doing nothing is nota title ofnobility,but a disgrace at which the richest blush. In London, for example, there are gentlemen, owners of millions, who work in industrial and com- mercial enterprises, who ocoupy themselves with science, art, or literature, travel abroad for distraction or instruction, or, at the worst, administer their estates, occupying theniselves with agricultural improvements.

"Yet I know gentlemen in Lombardy who have never even seen their estates !" In respect of No. 3 also, the Italian husband is of lower earth than the Anglo-Saxon, for Signor Mantegazza devotes a page to the dis- couragement of wife-murder. "I sympathise and condole," he says, "with the husband who kills the favoured lover," but-"to kill a woman is the most bestial of outrages, and I applaud those who take their own lives after committing this crime." It is a singular over- sight that an author who considers so many contingencies should have omitted to discuss the ditficult question of wife-beating, a course which may be held to lie somewhere midway between the indifference which he would no doubt deprecate, and the "Othelloism" which wields a lethal pillow. The admonitory Signor must have a fellow- feeling for Mr. H. G. Wells, for in the end his heroine becomes the wife of an engineer, and, we are given to understand, lives happily ever afterwards. It is to be hoped that in that capacity she followed the excellent advice of the book :- "Should your husband talk to you of his plans and enterprises, show you his designs and drawings, do not look bored or outside the pale of his studies."

It is well to adopt a sympathetic attitude even towards a triple expansion engine. Ap- parently it was a mere toss-up whether the fair Silvia did not wed a manufacturer (supposing him to be at the same time a Socialist) whom the author classes, as a husband, "far above merchants, shopkeepers, or even bankers." (The allusion, it should be explained, is to Italian bankers, who appear to be especially liable to defalcation and sudden beggary). He has no great objection to the lawyer, in spite of that learned man's "comfortable tendency to inter- change truth with falsehood"-again, let us hope, a criticism only applicable to the K.C. or King Victor Emmanuel. The worst of marrying a doctor is that :

"He may smell of iodoform or phenol, and involuntarily the thought may cross your mind at the dinner-table that the same hand now peeling an orange was perhaps an hour ago disseeting a dead body or operating a tumour." Besides, a doctor is either too busy or too poor, and-in Italy, of course-his wife has a tendency to become the feminine counterpart of No. 3 in the catalogue of undesirables. Am bitious ladies are urged to marry politicians ; and the scientist, once aloof and absorbed, "may now be an excellent husband." Two classes, however, must keep the Tyrant and therest company on the Index Expurgatorius :- "Never marry an artist unless he happens to be a genius or an angel.
"Never marry a mediocre author."

In any event the artist is unsatisfactory, for "his first love is Art, and you will always come after her;" and you cannot even have it out with her except in Bessie's way in "The Light that Failed." On the other hand, if the poet fulfils the necessary conditions he may be a successful spouse:--
"A literary man brings into home life more flowers than fruit; but flowers too are many beautiful things, and you will spend many
div.note: "The Art of Choosing a Husband." By Paolo Mantegazza. Translated from the Italian by Gabriel Claude Wharton. (Gay and Bird).
div.p: happy hours while your poet husband reads you with emotion the last pages of one of his books."
But in this case the wife must possess very superior qualifications; no doubt a list of them will be found in Signor Montegazza's previous volume on "The Art of Taking a Wife."

In a closing chapter the author counsels his charges not to be afraid of becoming old maids. If they endeavour to adhere strictly to his ex- cellent advice, it is highly probable that that will be their latter end. But it is a self-willed sex; and likely enough his very next reader, having determined on his representations to marry a manufacturer (who is also a Socialist) will go forth and take to herself a minor poet who is both a Tyrant and a Grumbler, as well as a Miser on account of circumstances over which he has no control.

div.head:
AEGYPTIACA.
BY JOSEPH OFFORD.
div.p: The long Aramaic papyrus of Persian times edited by Professor Euting and the other frag- mentary ones which have been dealt with by M. Clermont Ganneau, and Mr. Stanley A. Cook, are likely to be surpassed in interest by the Aramaic documents obtained by Mr. Mond last winter, and which are in the hands of Mr. Cowley of Oxford. Meanwhile Professor Sayce has published some Aramaic inscriptions from Egypt, one of which, coming from a quarry near Tourah, is important for the history of Cairo for it carried backward the application of the name of Babylon to Old Cairo to pre- Christian, and probably to the Persian, period. It is the record of one "Phuti son of Shaman the Babylonian."

It is generally imagined that all the ancient scribes of Egypt indited their writings only upon papyri, but this is not strictly correct, for sometimes leather of the nature of parchment was used. So far from this being a novelty invented in late times it, like everything Egyptian, goes back to an unknown antiquity, for a chapter of the "Book of the Dead" is said tohave been found under quite an early dynasty written upon leather and concealed beneath a statue. How many centuries must have lapsed for a chapter of the Ritual to have dropped out of the canon. Who can say ?

There is a document upon leather still in existence which came from Thebes, and it has been described a long time ago by M. Virey. It is of the time of Ramses II., more than a thousand years before parchment was used by the Greeks, and yet it is, what paleographers have supposed to have been a Roman practice, a palymsest manuscript. The fact that it was capable of being utilised as a palymsest probably is the cause of leather having been the material employed, because it was used for the purpose of engrossing monthly Pharaonic accounts. The figures were erased, the names remaining as before and the new set of monthly items written again.

This manusoript preserves the accounts or the "ahn," or outer domain of the royal palace, and is for the first month of spring, viz., Pachons of the 5th year of Ramses II. The "ahn" seems to have included the outer courtyard and Nile wharf, stables, warehouses, and work- shops, and as there was no coinage and much tribute and presents were paid in kind, this outer domain was of considerable size. It was distinct from the palace itself because we have papyri which provide us with tabulated accounts of goods delivered into the royal dwelling house proper, from the stores that had accumulated in the "ahn."

Doubtless the clerks in the exterior department had their lists checked by stock taking at various periods, allowance being made for items they had receipts for as having been handed over to the palace itself. The majority of items in this manuscript account relate to the delivery of bricks and timber, which seem to have formed the temple tribute from most of the provinces.

M. Virey deduces some interesting historical data from the text. It stops at the 15th day of Pachons of the King's 5th year. Now the epic poem of Pentaur tells us that on the 9th of the following month Epiphi, Rameses crossed the frontier at T'ar on his Kadesh campaign. To reach T'ar from Thebes by the 9th the scribe, if he were liable to military service, would have to leave soon after the 15th of Pachons, and doubtless with, or without, him would leave many of the Ahn chancery officials concerned in the memorandum.

It is quite possible that the author fell in one of the reckless charges of the Hittite charioteers, and as he never returned, his leather account book was mislaid and buried in the sand, to be restored to us some 3,000 years later.

There doubtless are still in the posession of Arab dealers in Cairo portions of the mass of manuscripts belonging to the Geniza of that city, the greater portion of which are now at Cambridge; for last January parts of these manuscripts were obtained by me which are now in the library of the McGill University at Montreal. One of these consisted of four paper leaves inscribed upon both sides in writing of about the 14th century with a text of the Midrash Rabbs.

Another of eight pages is noticeable because though an Arabic treatise it is written in Hebrew characters. The subject matter of the work is the treatment of the poor with special reference to Deutermomy XV. 7-11. It is written in the form of question and answer. Saadyah Ben Gaon is referred to. It is perhaps part of a lengthy Karaite commentary upon the Pentateuch.

The third document is unfortunately represented by only a single page. It is probably of the 13th century, and is a Rabbinic, not Karaite, composition. It is a rhymned text and, it is likely, was written with the object of its recital upon the "Day of Atonement." It concerns the functions of the High Priest in connection with Leviticus XVI. and is written in elegant Hebrew.

div.head: ANTHROPOLOGIE EGYPTIENNE.
div.p: M. Chantre est un savant consciencieux. Il nous a donné sur l'anthropologie égyptienne d'excellents ouvrages qui resteront comme des documents personnels de première main. Ces travaux ont nécessité de patientes recherches, de longs voyages dans le Caucase, l'Asie-Mi- neure et la Syrie. Cette fois, c'est l'Egypte qui a séduit M. Chantre. Il a étudié les différents types d'indigènes qui peuplent cette contrée célèbre par son antique civilisation. Il a relevé les différents caractères anthropologiques des habitants et les a compares aux momies des temps pharaoniques. Ses conclusions sont infi- niment intéressantes. Ce sont des constata- tions importantes pour la science et aux- quelles le détail des fouilles ajoute un attrait tout particulier. La première partie de ce nouvel ouvrage fait revivre fes mœurs, les coutumes des anciens égyptiens, leurs cérémonies funéraires et leur système d'em- baumement. Dans la seconde partie, l'au- teur nous décrit les populations comprises sous le nom de Soudanais, Arabes, Coptes, Fellahs, etc., et nous fait connattre leurs origines et leurs habitudes. M. Chantre a tout vu, tout contrôlé. Il a relevé non seulement des docu- ments ethnographiques, mais des clichés qui nous offrent la représentation vivante des indi- vidus. On peut dire que M. Chantre a fouillé le passé et le présent. Tout ce qui est mort. revit sous sa plume. Son beau livre n'est pas seulement un ouvrage scientifique qui ne sera pas égalé ; c'est un répertoire magnifiquement illustre que tous les lecteurs serieux liront avec le plus grand plaisir.
Les recherches anthropologiques en Egypte, par ERNEST CHANTRE.--Un vol. in-4, 320 p., 180 grav.--Rey, Lyon.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit --within certain necessary limits-- free discussion.

div.head: DANGERS OF CAIRO STREETS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,–Your columns are frequently recording the serious accidents which are occasioned by the breaking of overhead tramway wires ; but there is another danger which appears to pass unnoticed by the police, namely, the frequency with which animals are driven through the principal thoroughfares of Cairo unattended by responsible drovers. But a short time ago I saw a puny child in charge of two huge bulls ; and it was only yesterday that I observed three camels passing the Savoy Hotel accompanied. only by a little girl, who was holding on to the tail of the one in front, which she could barely reach. Everyone knows that accidents in such cases may happen at any moment, and it behoves the police to exercise greater super- vision than heretofore to prevent their occur- rence. I would strongly urge that animals should not be allowed to be driven through the streets unless in charge of a licensed drover, who should be required to wear a badge with a number upon it for the purpose of identifica- tion. If this recommendation were adopted and duly enforced, the Government would increase its revenue, and, at the same time, the public would be better protected from the risk of injury than it is at present.
I am, etc.,

div.head: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,-I think a word of praise is due to the police for the efficient way in which they are endeavouring to perform a somewhat delicate duty, viz., that of judging at a moment's notice whether in each individual case the complaint of cruelty is well-founded; for here as else- where it is possible to exaggerate our feelings ot sympathy for dumb animals. Some nervous old ladies with philanthropic propensities would perhaps think that the weight of a few cabbages was an invasion of the rights of our inarticulate charges. The police, therefore, have a difficult task to perform, especially where the complainant is a European. A case happened this morning, however, which proved to me that the instructions given as to their proper functions are not being neglected by those who are called upon to carry them out; nay, more, that the police are cheerfully and intelligently executing the orders given to them. I saw a miserably fed donkey fall under his burden. At the moment, I was some distance off. The man in charge of him beat him unmercifully to make him rise, but without effect. When I arrived on the scene I made him desist. The load was removed and after some little time the donkey got upon his feet again. Notwithstanding my protests-I am only a woman-the driver, with the assistance of two bystanders--donkey boys--placed the load upon his back again. He managed to move. I looked round for a shawish. There was none within hailing distance. In a minute or so, however, a 'carro' passed with a shawish riding leisurely upon it. He was evidently off duty as he had no badge upon his arm. I called to him. Without waiting for the 'carro' to stop he came to my assistance. In my broken Arabic I explained to him the case. He never hesitated for a moment. He did not

even ask for my card, but marched off the donkey and driver to the caracol. That is what I call business. I know the time, not very long ago, when there would have been endless discussion, resulting in the exhaustion of my vocabulary and powers of comprehension, and the escape of the brutal donkey driver into the bargain. Things are indeed changing for the better. A straw shows which way the wind blows. The Egyptians are not slow to learn, and singularly unprejudiced in secular matters.
I am, etc.,

div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Bovril is an ideal food for the strong and the weak. Bovril imparts extra vigor to the healthy, greater strenght to the ailing. Bovril is, moreover, a true friend in the kitchen. It adds nourishment, and gives a delightful "twang" to soups, sauces, gravies and entrees.

N.B. Tous les mardis et les jeudis de chaque semaine, pendant la saison théâtrale à l'Opéra Khédivial le dernier train partira de Bab-el-Louk à 12h.45 au lieu de 12h.30.
